ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 6 - Weekly problem sets, mostly from the text book. In class final exam.
4-6 hours per week
4-5 hours
3 hours.
It was about 10-12 hours per week.
8-15 hours per week.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: This course gives a deeper biostat perspective to the Epi you already know from Epi I and II. The course was mostly manageable, but at some points went off into calculus and derivations that will lose most of the non-biostat students.

the lectures were very dull and not interesting at all. the material presented was too theoretical and not enough emphasis on applications. i walked away from the class not knowing what i got out of it. it was mainly a theory course that show the proofs behind odds ratios. this class should have been taught as a full semester with separate lectures emphasizing theory and concepts and lectures emphasizing applications.
This course was not valuable for EPI knowledge. Often CDE professors disagreed with what we were taught in this course and therefore the knowledge is not practical and applicable in an epi sense.
It is a good course. But maybe it is a little bit too short (only half semester).

I am very disappointed by this course. I was really looking forward to learning about how to do survival analysis step-by-step, from scratch. Instead, the class seem to catered to biostatistics majors because almost every session resulted in the instructor showing mathematical proofs on the chalk board. I'm wonder how much of this is useful for applied researchers?What would be helpful are step-by-step sessions on how to conduct survival using SAS, interpreting the output, understanding papers that used survival analysis, and how to write up the results. Instead such indispensable topics were brushed through and assumed we could digest from pages of unintelligible SAS code uploaded on classes V2.What would improve is to have a lecture tutorial system. During the tutorial the TA could go through how to actually conduct survival analysis step-by-step, assuming no prior knowledge, and explaining the SAS code step by step.

The overall course was very good and provided and in depth look at epidemiological statistics. Like the survival analysis class, I think this should really be a full semester course. I think that we went through the last section extremely quickly. Having a full semester would allow us more time to digest that material.
informative and useful, but it's too fast-paced
Good, but could be more clear

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Hongyu Zhao  This was Dr. Zhao's first time teaching this course. He is a very nice guy and clearly knows his stuff. Overall, I think the biggest challenge was that this material seems really basic from his perspective, and he doesn't know how to relate it to students for whom it is a lot more advanced. As this was his first time with the course, parts were a bit rough and he did not have a good sense of the amount of material that he could cover in one class. I expect those things will improve each year.
Instructor: Hongyu Zhao  nice approachable professor but not a great teacher. too much emphasis on proofs

Instructor: Hongyu Zhao  Dr. Zhao is a poor instructor who derives formulas constantly without providing the why or how behind the calculus. His slides reflect that he put little effort into the course and was unsure of what he was really teaching. If Dr. Zhao teaches this course in the future, calculus should be listed as a pre-requisite.
Instructor: Hongyu Zhao  Professor Zhao is kind and helpful. He always explains things clearly.

Instructor: Hongyu Zhao  consider the class composition during preparation. This class does not only contain only biostats majors. on the contrary a majority are not and who have no survival background. instead of 80% focus on mathematical proofs, won't it be more beneficial to balance it out with a step-by-step process on how to do survival analysis and explaining SAS code? what we need to take away is how to use SAS to do survival and not a treatise on the mathematics used by the program.

Instructor: Hongyu Zhao  I think that Hongyu was very approachable, flexible and a good professor. This was an enormous amount of material which had to be fit into a small amount of time. Given the constraints, I feel he did a very good job.
Instructor: Hongyu Zhao  very learned and clear about all the concepts.But he shows not very responsive to students' need

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Greg is one of my favorite biostat TAs. He is always very accessible by email and at office hours and is a fantastic resource when you need the information broken down to a more understandable level.
good TA but was rather harsh with the grading.
The TA is kind and helpful. He prepared detailed answers to homework.
He/she should conduct tutorial sessions and prepare step-by-step notes on how to do survival analysis on SAS. Not once did he/she appear during lectures to find out how students are coping.
Greg was available and easily accessible. Very clear and knew the material
good

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: If this course is not required for you, I would recommend itas an elective if you want to keep up some biostat after first year without driving yourself too crazy. You will be happier if you remember some calculus, but can get by with faking it. Having an Epi background was critical for this class; without it I would have been completely lost.
i would not recommend taking this class. only take it if it's required.

Unless you are required to take this course, do not bother taking it. According to numerous CDE professors the information taught is not applicable and, therefore, spending time on derivations for homework is a futile act. This course does not produce any valuable results.
I would recommend it to a fellow student.

Totally unhelpful for someone who wants to learn survival from scratch. I left this course traumatized by the sheer amount of mathematical proofs performed feverishly by the instructor during class time.
In depth coverage of epidemiological statistics.
generally recommend
